;;2021 年阿尔宾·库尔蒂在布鲁塞尔
;

;欧盟斡旋的科索沃和塞尔维亚之间的谈判已经变得如此科索沃总理表示，单方面认为他们已经走进了死胡同。

;

;欧洲主导的十多年来的调解努力，最近在摩尔多瓦和布鲁塞尔，未能实现两国关系正常化贝尔格莱德仍然拒绝承认 2008 年根据联合国资助的计划宣布的科索沃独立。

;

;周日，紧张局势在;科索沃北部一名警察被杀，另一名警察受伤，这是该地区几个月来的首次暴力事件。

;

;总理阿尔宾·库尔蒂 (Albin Kurti) 在周末暴力事件发生前接受《卫报》采访时表示，持续的不稳定使该地区“成为地缘政治的游乐场”。俄罗斯联邦和中华人民共和国的比赛”。

;

;库尔蒂将他与塞尔维亚总统亚历山大·武契奇于 9 月 14 日举行的最近一次流产的会面描述为一场灾难，并表示欧盟特使米罗斯拉夫·莱恰克表示”，“失去了中立性”。

;

;根据库尔蒂的说法，莱恰克未能在会议之前向科索沃人传达塞尔维亚的书面谈判立场，直到会谈破裂后才向他们提出。库尔蒂说，这份立场文件已经有六个月了。

;

;“这种方法没有进一步进展，”库尔蒂说。 “9 月 14 日的[会议]显示了旧方法的局限性。”

;

;他指责武契奇在会谈期间对他进行侮辱，他说这已经成为一种经常发生的事情，而调解员却没有做出任何努力来阻止

;

;“这两年他经常用塞尔维亚语冒犯和咒骂，”库尔蒂说。 “我要求调解人阻止他并谴责他，但这从未发生。”

;

;6 月 1 日在摩尔多瓦举行的另一场峰会上，法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙、德国总统奥拉夫·肖尔茨和欧盟外交政策负责人出席了会议。据其办公室称，武契奇针对科索沃总统维约萨·奥斯马尼进行了诽谤。

;

;“他对科索沃总统及其随行人员使用了贬义和非人性的词‘老鼠’，”布莱里姆说贝拉，奥斯马尼的幕僚长。 “武契奇的脾气反映了他的个性和他无法接受不同意见的态度。”

;

;一位消息人士称，尽管马克龙和肖尔茨无法理解他在说什么，但武契奇的“肢体语言表明他很恼怒”并且没有库尔蒂不愿具体说明塞尔维亚总统据称对他使用了哪些绰号，但科索沃外交官表示，在早些时候的会议中使用的攻击性词语之一是“;shiptar” ;”，塞尔维亚语中对阿尔巴尼亚人的种族歧视。

;

;“这感觉就像一个校霸被学校管理部门授予荣誉，只不过在这种情况下，校霸犯下了种族灭绝罪库尔蒂说：“塞尔维亚总统办公室没有回复评论请求。” img src="https://media.guim.co.uk/57ab5df1d719a43f11c22a53e3a39687588a241c/185_338_5674_3404/1000.jpg" alt="Aleksandar Vučić、Josep Borrell、Miroslav Lajčák 和 Albin Kurti 于 9 月 14 日在布鲁塞尔举行会议“宽度=”1000“ height="600">;

; ;

;种族诽谤对该地区产生了特殊的影响，因为它们与 20 世纪 90 年代末时任总统领导下的塞尔维亚军队残酷的平叛和种族清洗运动相呼应，;斯洛博丹·米洛舍维奇;。超过 10,000 人被杀，其中绝大多数来自科索沃占多数的阿尔巴尼亚族。

;

;2 月份，武契奇和库尔蒂在布鲁塞尔会面并就“正常化之路”达成一致，欧洲调解人认为他们已经取得了突破。 .

;

;根据协议，两国将承认彼此的护照、国旗和标志，塞尔维亚不会反对科索沃加入任何国际组织，科索沃将“确保科索沃适当水平的自我管理”。尽管武契奇在下个月在北马其顿奥赫里德湖举行的另一次会议上口头批准了布鲁塞尔文件和执行附件，但武契奇拒绝签署其中任何一项，并很快又收回了承诺，加剧了科索沃的不信任

;

;在欧盟官员称赞奥赫里德湖项目取得成功后，武契奇出现在塞尔维亚电视台上，向他的追随者保证他没有签署任何协议，因为“我的右手疼痛难忍”，并补充道：“这种疼痛是意料之中的。”持续四年。”

;

;此后不久，4月贝尔格莱德直接违反奥赫里德协议，反对科索沃加入欧洲委员会。

;

;自乌克兰战争爆发以来科索沃认为，优先事项已经发生变化，以确保塞尔维亚不会进一步受到俄罗斯的影响。它声称欧盟和美国反而将批评集中在库尔蒂政府没有建立塞族占多数的市镇协会以给予塞族地区更多自治权上。

;

;目前尚不清楚两者之间存在实质性差异。欧盟和塞尔维亚的立场。两者都要求科索沃首先对塞族城市采取行动，作为取得进展的先决条件。库尔蒂拒绝在塞尔维亚没有采取相应措施的情况下采取这一行动，并指出武契奇的记录中没有任何内容表明他可以信任。

;

;爱德华·约瑟夫 (Edward P Joseph)，前安全和组织科索沃代表团副团长库尔蒂认为，在欧洲的合作中，谨慎是有道理的。

;

;“他要求美国和欧盟就这项协议的塞尔维亚方面的执行提供真正的具体性和真正的保证，这并没有错。”约瑟夫现在是约翰·霍普金斯大学高级国际研究学院的高级研究员。 “这是一个战略问题。他将把自治权交给一个由一个更大、敌对邻国控制的分离主义组织。”

;

;库尔蒂说，他参加了 9 月 14 日举行的最新一次会议，提出了如何安排科索沃和塞尔维亚步骤的建议。据欧盟特使拉查克称，这些提议不会奏效，因为它们与塞尔维亚的立场相冲突。当科索沃总理要求查看塞尔维亚的立场文件时，莱恰克表示，该立场文件已在会议前交给库尔蒂的副手。

;

;然而，副手说他什么也没收到，于是库尔蒂去质问莱恰克，后者然后表示他的团队仍在“尝试从他们的文件中检索该文档”。

; ;

;根据库尔蒂的说法，丢失的文件包含库尔蒂说，塞尔维亚甚至在三月份协议之前就起草了该协议，并且坚称在库尔蒂创建塞尔维亚市政协会之前不可能取得任何进展。在他眼中，莱查克毫无疑问地接受了塞尔维亚人的条件。

;

;“这就是我感到震惊的原因。我很震惊，”库尔蒂说。 “我认为欧盟 27 国并未获悉此事。他们将这项非常重要的工作外包给了这个失去中立性的人。”

;

;Lajčák 办公室拒绝就库尔蒂对事件的说法发表评论。

;

;欧盟外交事务首席发言人事务部表示，库尔蒂的说法“不反映事实且不准确”。他说;27个成员国重申;全力支持对话、博雷尔领导会谈以及莱恰克。他批评库尔蒂违反保密规定。

;

;“欧盟27国还提醒库尔蒂先生有责任在对话中维护保密原则，这是任何政治敏感谈判进程的关键组成部分，”说发言人。

;

;美国和欧盟的做法引起了其他地方的批评。八月，;包括美国、德国和英国议会外交事务委员会主席在内的一批西方著名政客;写信给美国和欧盟领导人，敦促改变他们所说的以塞尔维亚为中心的做法。

;

;在一封措辞强硬的信中，他们敦促“国际社会从我们的过去中吸取教训，确保我们不会对巴尔干地区采取以贝尔格莱德为中心的政策”。

;

;Aleksandra Tomanić，该组织的执行董事支持民主的倡导组织欧洲巴尔干基金会表示，欧盟会议变得毫无意义，甚至适得其反。

;

;“在双方目标完全相反的情况下‘促进’对话是不够的， ”托马尼奇说道。 “正如我们现在所看到的，提供办公空间和饼干并持续多年的‘对话’将导致更多的挫败感、进一步增加不信任并最终导致紧张局势。”

;

;经营科索沃一家公司的多尼卡·埃米尼 (Donika Emini)名为 CiviKos Platform 的非政府组织联盟一致认为，由于库尔蒂的“误判”，他“失去了北部的塞族人，需要很长时间才能修复这种关系”。

;

;不过，她说库尔蒂是对的建立一个塞尔维亚城市协会，而无需欧盟和美国就与塞尔维亚实现正常化的进展提供坚实的保证。

;

;否则，埃米尼说，“他们将成为另一层治理，科索沃内部将更加功能失调，而且它不会在国际上或与塞尔维亚有关的方面产生任何影响。”

;

;埃米尼补充道：“我认为他们过于乐观地认为，如果他们向库尔蒂施加压力并容纳塞尔维亚人，武契奇就会转向西方。约瑟夫认为，西方对塞尔维亚没有任何影响力，而四个北约成员国——希腊、罗马尼亚、斯洛伐克和西班牙——仍然不承认科索沃，主要是出于对先例的担心。

;

;作为打破僵局的一种方式，他认为乌克兰对科索沃的承认可能会成为说服四个欧洲顽固分子效仿的催化剂。库尔蒂说，他在会见弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基时提出了这个问题。

;

;他补充道：“我相信乌克兰的承认将是彼此深刻的理解和团结一致反对独裁侵略。”

; Sun, 24 Sep 2023 20:22:01 +0800 First evacuees from Nagorno-Karabakh cross into Armeniahttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/24/first-evacuees-from-nagorno-karabakh-cross-into-armenia-azerbaijan
;;2023-09-24T12:11:29Z;
;
;;周日，人们在边境小镇科尔尼佐尔附近的亚美尼亚外交部哨所前等待登记
;

;第一批从饱受战争蹂躏的纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫分离地区撤离的人员已进入亚美尼亚，在经历了 10 个月的封锁和阿塞拜疆密集的军事进攻后与家人团聚。

;

;Rima下午早些时候，她的两个女儿越过边境，迎接她的哥哥，带着巧克力和糖果等待着。

;

;这是她们近一年来第一次见面，一家人拥抱在一起，当他们准备前往靠近边境的戈里斯市附近的亲戚家时，他们哭了。

;

;“我现在很高兴，”里马说。她的兄弟说：“我一直都知道他们会来，我知道他们会没事的。”

;

;纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫分裂的亚美尼亚政府官员表示，他们计划从该地区疏散数千名流离失所者。进入亚美尼亚。

;

;阿塞拜疆对该领土的封锁导致当地首都斯捷潘纳克特及周边地区食品、燃料和水严重短缺。

; ;

;当地亚美尼亚族政府呼吁阿塞拜疆打通沿拉钦走廊进入亚美尼亚的道路，允许人道主义援助进入纳戈尔诺，并允许当地民众离开纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫。许多人担心阿塞拜疆当局控制后会发生种族清洗运动。

;

;当地政府表示，撤离人员将由俄罗斯维和人员陪同从有争议地区越过边境进入亚美尼亚。

;

;“亲爱的同胞们，我们想通知你们，在俄罗斯维和人员的陪同下，因最近的军事行动而无家可归并表示愿意离开的家庭将被转移到亚美尼亚。” “政府将在不久的将来发布有关其他人口群体搬迁的信息。”

;

;这个分离州（也称为阿尔扎赫）的地方官员早些时候表示，他们计划疏散估计超过阿塞拜疆发布“重新整合”领土的计划后，有 12 万人前往亚美尼亚。

;

;纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫是一个山区，许多亚美尼亚人将其视为自己的祖先家园，但国际上承认其为阿塞拜疆领土。自 20 世纪 90 年代初以来，它一直由亚美尼亚当地政府管辖。与阿塞拜疆停火后，政府现已接近崩溃。

;
;

;;相关：;;“没有出路”：纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫居民最担心的是阿塞拜疆军队控制了控制;

; ;

;地方当局已做好疏散准备。一名卫报记者在亚美尼亚与纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫边境附近的一个新检查站被警察拦住，并被告知由于疏散计划，通往道路的通道现已被封锁。

;

;亚美尼亚政府表示，已准备好迎接 12 万亚美尼亚同胞，他们很可能很快就会离开。

;

;“我们的政府将热烈欢迎来自纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫的兄弟姐妹，”亚美尼亚总理尼科尔·帕希尼扬 (Nikol Pashinyan) 表示，在周日的现场讲话中。

;

;“纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫的亚美尼亚人仍然面临种族清洗的危险，”他说。 “人道主义物资已于近日抵达纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫，但这并没有改变局势。”

;

;“如果不为纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫的亚美尼亚人在家中创造真正的生活条件，也没有建立有效的机制，如果保护其免受种族清洗，那么纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫的亚美尼亚人将被驱逐出家园作为唯一出路的可能性就会增加。”

;

;他批评了一个由俄罗斯主导的安全集团，而亚美尼亚是其中的一个成员。成员表示，集体安全条约组织在防止进一步暴力方面“无效”。

;

;目前尚不清楚未来几天可能有多少人从纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫撤离。

; < p>;俄罗斯维和人员表示，近 800 名流离失所者一直住在该特派团用作基地的机场，其中许多人逃离阿塞拜疆本周进攻中袭击的小村庄和城镇。

;

;数十人据报道，还有数千人被困在斯捷潘纳克特，新一轮暴力事件后，数千名流离失所者涌入该市。

; Sun, 24 Sep 2023 20:22:01 +0800 Tigist Assefa smashes marathon world record in Berlin in new £400 shoeshttps://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/sep/24/tigist-assefa-smashes-marathon-world-record-in-berlin-in-new-400-shoes
;;2023-09-24T11:24:52Z;
;
;;埃塞俄比亚选手 Tigist Assefa 在打破女子马拉松世界纪录两分多钟后庆祝。
;

;在柏林最寂静的早晨，一场海啸般的表演。它来自埃塞俄比亚的 Tigist Assefa，她以 2 小时 11 分 53 秒的成绩将世界纪录打破，超过 26.2 英里的惊人里程重新定义了许多人对女子马拉松的想象。
;
;事实上，这位 29 岁的埃塞俄比亚选手以 2 分 11 秒的成绩打破了布里吉德·科斯盖 (Brigid Kosgei) 在 2019 年创下的最佳成绩，这已经足够了不起了。然而，她通过勃兰登堡门回家的方式表明她还可以走得更快。

;
;

;;相关：;;埃塞俄比亚选手 Gudaf Tsegay 以近五秒的速度打破 5,000m 世界纪录;

;
;

;这也是一场将重新点燃超级鞋大战的胜利。阿塞法脚上的是新款 Adizero Adios Pro Evo 1s，阿迪达斯声称“采用挑战赛车极限的独特技术进行增强”。无论这些说法的真实性如何，这双鞋——周二以 400 英镑的天价发售——现在肯定会有很多人购买，即使价格令人瞠目结舌。
;
;到了柏林，这里与瓦伦西亚一起被认为是赛道上最快的赛道，大多数人的焦点都集中在传奇人物肯尼亚埃鲁德·基普乔格能否打破他的男子世界纪录。尽管他以 2:02:42 的成绩以 31 秒的优势赢得了第五个柏林冠军，这是他辉煌职业生涯中第五快的成绩，但这一天的全部内容都是关于阿塞法的。
;
; 对于女子比赛的前三分之一， 12人一组都以世界纪录的配速奔跑。但当阿塞法将节奏提高到 8 到 10 英里之间时，她发现自己只有起搏器陪伴。
;
; 中途分站时间为 1 小时 06 分 20 秒，这使她有望打破比世界纪录快了一分钟多。然而，她在下半场速度更快，载入史册。

; ;

;让阿塞法的表现更加引人注目的是，她去年才参加了自己的第一次马拉松比赛，成绩是由于健康问题，沙特阿拉伯利雅得的正常时间为 2:34:01。

;
;

;;相关：;;莫法拉退役后留下了什么遗产？嗯，这很复杂|肖恩·英格尔;

;
;

;然而，在 2022 年柏林马拉松比赛中，他以 2 小时 15 分 37 秒的成绩取得了令人震惊的胜利，当时是有史以来第三快的成绩，这更好地预示了即将发生的事情。

;

; Sun, 24 Sep 2023 19:22:01 +0800 An old master? No, it’s an image AI just knocked up … and it can’t be copyrightedhttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/sep/24/an-old-master-no-its-an-image-ai-just-knocked-up-and-it-cant-be-copyrighted
;;2023-09-24T09:00:18Z;
;
;;美国法院裁定，使用人工智能创建的 Théâtre d'Opéra Spatial 不受版权保护
;< p>;在裁决获奖图像不能获得版权后，人工智能在艺术中的使用面临挫折，因为它不是由人类充分制作的。

;

;该决定由美国版权局做出审查委员会发现，在 2022 年科罗拉多州博览会年度艺术竞赛中获得第一名的人工智能生成图像 Théâtre d'Opéra Spatial 不符合资格，因为版权保护“排除了非人类制作的作品”。

;

;艺术家 Jason Allen 声称，他使用在线人工智能平台 Midjourney 可以声称自己是该图像的作者，因为他“输入了一系列提示，调整了场景，选择了要关注的部分，并决定了图像的基调” ”。但委员会裁定，“如果作品的所有‘传统作者身份要素’都是由机器制作的，则该作品缺乏人类作者身份，该办公室不会对其进行登记。”。

;

;艾伦告诉 ;普韦布洛酋长;当地报纸称他“想利用人工智能艺术作品发表声明。我觉得我已经做到了这一点，而且我不会为此道歉。”

;

;这个决定是作家、演员、音乐家和摄影师;声称人工智能正在威胁他们的工作;，并遵循上个月美国联邦法院的类似裁决斯蒂芬·塞勒 (Stephen Thaler) 拥有的人工智能计算机系统创建的图像不能获得版权，因为人类是“有效版权主张的重要组成部分”。

;

;法院现在经常提及版权下的人类作者要求法，包括驳回克里斯蒂娜·卡什塔诺娃（Kristina Kashtanova）对《黎明查莉娅》（Zarya of the Dawn）的版权主张，该书是一本“由非人类灵性生物‘创作’”的书。该裁决指出，版权旨在保护“这不是神的创造物”。

;

;有关该问题的判例法现在还包括驳回代表自拍猴子提起的版权诉讼。但在塞勒案中，贝丽尔·豪厄尔法官确实承认人类正在“接近版权的新领域”，艺术家将使用人工智能作为创作新作品的工具。

;
;

;;相关：< /span>;;新报告显示，绝大多数 NFT 现在毫无价值;< /p>;

;

;“评委不懂艺术，或者对一种非常具体的技能有一种老式的想法，这种技能能够手工再现一个非常具体的世界视野，”说纽约艺术家兼评论家沃尔特·罗宾逊（Walter Robinson）一直在使用 Midjourney，他说，“只是为了好玩”。

;

;“显然，使用任何类型的工具，无论是画笔还是计算机程序，都具有创造性。一切都由人类特工指挥，”罗宾逊补充道。 “当我在 Midjourney 中输入提示并重新输入直到得到我想要的内容时，确实我不是在画画，而是在使用工具制作图像。”

;

;人工智能不是只有创新才能困扰艺术界。根据 dappGambl 网站，对相关领域（NFT 或不可替代代币）的分析发现，在超过 73,000 名研究对象中，95% 属于“;没有实际用途或价值;”，上市两年后;2021年达到220亿美元（180亿英镑）的峰值;。它说：“这一令人畏惧的现实应该成为对欣快感的清醒检查。”

; Sun, 24 Sep 2023 15:52:01 +0800 ‘There is no way out’: residents of Nagorno-Karabakh fear worst as Azerbaijan’s troops take controlhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/24/fear-rises-food-runs-short-karabakh-azerbaijan
;;2023-09-24T04:00:13Z;
;
;;A soldier looks away from the camera down a road that can be seen winding through bare, rolling hills into the distance
;

;Anna has already survived nine months of a blockade, then a new Azerbaijani offensive that brought shelling and gunfire to her city, and then days hiding in a basement.

;

;Now, ;even as fighting dies down;, life in her hometown in Nagorno-Karabakh is a struggle to survive, with shortages of nearly all critical goods, whole families sleeping rough or scrabbling for food after fleeing their villages, and an information vacuum that has separated loved ones and fuelled fears of the worst in towns occupied by Azerbaijan.

;

;“They have genocidal intentions toward us, they have proved that,” Anna told the; Observer; by telephone from Stepanakert. “They subjected us to starvation for more than nine months, and then they killed more than 200 soldiers, more than 40 civilians, children. You cannot live in peace with these people.”

;

;In dark towns and villages, with little food and no phone signal, ethnic Armenians in Karabakh are scrambling to find loved ones while many fear what could happen if Azerbaijani soldiers come into their homes before they find a way to escape. “I am a person who is active on social media,” said Anna. “I have also been involved in journalism … It's very dangerous for me personally to be here. It's dangerous for anyone to be here.”

; ;

;Karabakh is a mountainous region that Armenians have claimed as an ancestral homeland but which has been internationally recognised as part of Azerbaijan since the fall of the Soviet Union. Many Azeris were forced out of the region during a bloody war in the 1990s that ended with large swathes of Karabakh under the control of a breakaway ethnic-Armenian state called Artsakh.

;

;Border clashes have periodically flared up since then, and in 2020 Azerbaijan launched a huge offensive that ended in a decisive defeat for Armenia, as well as numerous accusations of war crimes. Azerbaijan forces ;took control of the historic city of Shusha; and forced Armenia to sign a controversial ceasefire agreement involving the introduction of Russian peacekeepers.

;

;Last week, Azerbaijan launched a new offensive, forcing the breakaway republic to agree to disband its territorial defence forces and enter talks that it said would lead to the “reintegration” of Azerbaijani lands.

;

;Stories from ethnic Armenians in Artsakh paint a picture of the disintegration of a state and the deprivations of war. After three decades of self-rule, many have watched their lives collapse in a matter of weeks.

; ;

;“We have lost everything,” said another resident of Stepanakert, who spoke briefly via the messaging app Telegram on Thursday. “Mainly, I am just thinking about where to get enough water and food for my children. I have collected just the things that we will need to go [to Armenia], when we think it is safe to go on the roads. Right now, there is no way out.”

;

;Marut Vanyan, a freelance journalist living in Stepanakert who has chronicled the toll that the war has taken using X (formerly Twitter), wrote: “Living all my 40 [years] here, I don't feel this city any more.” With no electricity, he wrote, the city smells of wood smoke as residents go outdoors to cook on open fires. The hospital, where some of the hundreds of war wounded have been treated in overwhelmed wards, was, he wrote, “just horrible”.

;

;Others have described exhausted doctors and nurses treating an influx of war wounded, many of them young men scarcely older than 18. The smell at the hospital – which is also one of just three places in the city where people can charge their phones – is said to be overpowering.

;

;Artak Beglaryan, a former human rights ombudsman who has remained in Stepanakert, said all goods – fuel, electricity, water, and especially food – were “running out”.

;

;“The hunger is quite a serious problem now,” he said. “There are thousands of people. Maybe 15,000 or 20,000 displaced from their villages – some of them occupied, others just risky and dangerous. Mostly they are in Stepanakert in basements and streets, and we have serious problems supplying them with food.”

;

;The humanitarian situation is dire as the effects of the blockade are compounded by the destruction of war. “No electricity, no gas, no food – people who left their villages and are scared to stay in the city went to the airport,” said Ruben Vardanyan, a former senior official in the breakaway republic and a wealthy businessman. “There are a lot of kids, pregnant women, old people who just spend their nights in the grass in the ground without anything. No toilets, no water. No communication because the telephones cannot be recharged.”

;

;The number of estimated casualties from the war has soared even higher. Vardanyan estimated that 500 people were still considered missing .

;

;“People are really nervous about trying to find their relatives and friends,” he said. “It's quite a bad mood.”

;

;Many have posted on Facebook and other social media to try to locate their loved ones. “All together, we are looking for a woman and her 4 children,” read one post. “Please. According to our last information, the woman was in Kusapat village of Martakert region with her 4 children. The evening before the war they were already in the basement. However, up to this moment there is no news or connection with them. Whoever has any information, please call this phone number.”

;

;Anna said: “We don't know what's happening to half the population of Artsakh right now. I know personally a lot of people who I cannot find because there is no connection.”

;

;Armenians have demanded that Azerbaijan agree to open up a humanitarian corridor, allowing aid in and refugees out. The key conduit is the Lachin corridor, a winding highway that leads from the Armenian city of Goris through the village of Tegh before crossing into Karabakh and the city of Berdzor, which Azerbaijan calls Lachin. Armenian police have established a checkpoint that prevents regular citizens from driving further into Karabakh, where the road is blocked by Russian peacekeepers and Azerbaijani soldiers.

; ;

;Last week, Armenians gathered for a protest in Republic Square in Yerevan, Armenia's capital. Among them was Lucy Muradyan, who was born in the Hadrut region and has lost touch with her family in Karabakh. “We are here in the square because our relatives, our parents, our family members are there surrounded by [Azerbaijani] troops,” she said. “Now the only thing we want is for our loved ones to be safely taken so that the road is open: men, women and children. Not just women and children, as it's currently said.”

;

;Fears that men could be filtered out at Azerbaijani checkpoints and tried as terrorists for fighting in local defence forces go back to before this month's offensive, when men travelling from Karabakh into Armenia were sometimes “kidnapped” at a checkpoint held by Azerbaijan along the Lachin corridor.

;

;Locals fear a repeat of the atrocities of the 2020 war, when Azerbaijani forces were filmed mutilating and torturing Armenian soldiers and civilians. In a ;2020 investigation;, the ;Guardian; confirmed the identities of two men beheaded in gruesome videos put online by Azerbaijani troops associated with far-right groups. The men had refused to leave their village ahead of the onslaught.

;

;Videos have already appeared online showing Azerbaijani troops firing automatic rifles at civilian homes. Ahead of a potential takeover by Azerbaijani's forces, people have even begun to destroy local archives to prevent them from falling into enemy hands, said Vardanyan, the former senior official.

;

;The Lachin corridor remains closed. At a police checkpoint near the town of Kornidzor on Friday, a dozen or so men from Karabakh waited for news in the hope that their relatives might have made it to the border. But no one has been let out. One father of two smoked nervously as he looked across the valley into Karabakh, where his children live with their mother. He was trapped outside the region when Azerbaijan launched its blockade nine months ago and has not seen them since.

;

;Andranik, also from Karabakh, was dressed in camouflage as he stood at the police checkpoint. He had managed to move his family out, he said, but was worried for other relatives and friends still trapped in the region. “We have to save them,” he said, shaking his head. “Otherwise the worst will happen to them too.”

;Braverman has ;previously made clear that; she will do “whatever it takes” to send asylum seekers to Rwanda – a plan that has been blocked by the courts. ;

;Enver Solomon, chief executive of the Refugee Council, warned that attacks on the ECHR went against Britain's historic support for such treaties. “Our nation has long demonstrated a deep commitment to providing sanctuary to those fleeing persecution and conflict,” he said.

;

;“This proud legacy is a testament to our values of compassion, empathy and solidarity. Abandoning these principles is not an option; we must stand firm in our commitment to refugees and to the international frameworks that were created to protect them.

;

;“What we need is a fair process for people who come here in search of safety and protection. Instead of threatening to abandon the frameworks and conventions that protect refugees' rights, we should be addressing the real issues in the asylum system, such as the record backlog, and providing safe routes for those in need of protection, including refugee visas, resettlement and family reunion schemes.”

;

;Human rights lawyers working with Ukraine's public prosecutor are preparing a war crimes dossier to submit to the international criminal court (ICC) accusing Russia of deliberately causing starvation during the 18-month-long conflict.

;

;The aim is to document instances where the Russian invaders used hunger as a weapon of war, providing evidence for the ICC to launch the first prosecution of its kind that could indict the Russian president, Vladimir Putin.

;

;Yousuf Khan, a senior lawyer with law firm Global Rights Compliance, said “the weaponisation of food has taken place in three phases,” starting with the initial invasion where Ukrainian cities were besieged and food supplies cut.

;

;Among the incidents documented was when ;20 civilians were killed in Chernihiv; in the early morning of 16 March 2022, when Russian fragmentation bombs exploded outside a supermarket in the city where Ukrainians were queueing for bread and food.

;

;Investigators are also focusing on the ;siege of Mariupol;, Khan added. Food supplies were cut to the city and humanitarian relief corridors blocked or bombed, making it very difficult or impossible for desperate, starving civilians to escape.

;

;The second phase includes the destruction of food and water supplies as well as energy sources across Ukraine during the fighting, which the lawyer described as “objects indispensable to the survival of the civilian population”.

;

;Such attacks, Khan argued, were “not crimes of result but crimes of intent” because “if you are taking out objects that civilians need, like energy infrastructure in the dead of winter, there is a foreseeability to your actions”.

;

;Cities such as Mykolaiv in the south were left without drinking water from early in the conflict after Russian forces captured the pumping station that supplied it. The remaining residents were forced to rely on water being driven in daily to ensure they could drink and wash safely.

;

;The third element is Russian attempts to prevent or restrict exports of Ukrainian food. “Then we've seen Russia attack grain facilities on the Danube and engage in muscle flexing on the Black Sea,” Khan said, citing reports from Ukrainian officials that 270,000 tonnes of the foodstuff were destroyed in late July and early August.

;

;Fresh accusations that Russia sought to starve Ukrainians are particularly emotive in the light of the two countries' history: in 1932-33, millions died of hunger in the ;Holodomor;, an enforced famine engineered by Joseph Stalin's Soviet government.

;

;But they have been given a renewed emphasis after the passage of a UN security council resolution in 2018 which condemned the use of starvation as a weapon of war, and revisions to the ICC's governing Rome statute in 2019, to expand the type of cases that can be brought.

;

;GRC is working with Ukrainian prosecutors until the end of next year to compile the dossier. The intention is to make a filing under article 15 of the Rome statute, allowing third parties to send information on alleged war crimes to the ICC's prosecutor. It would be up to the prosecutor, based in The Hague, to decide whether to proceed.

;

;Part of the lawyers' effort will be to identify perpetrators, including whether to call for the indictment of Putin as happened in March when the ICC ;issued an arrest warrant; for the president for overseeing the “unlawful deportation” of Ukrainian children to Russia from territories occupied during the war.

;

;Similar could be argued for starvation crimes, Khan said. “Putin could bear responsibility for having committed the acts directly, jointly with others and/or through others,” he argued, and for a failure to exercise proper control over Russian military or others accused of specific criminal acts.

;

;The lawyers work with open source intelligence specialists to detail examples of war crimes and engage in damage mapping analysis; collate relevant data, such as a count of aid convoys being rejected; and study statements made by Putin and other leaders, down to a local level, as they seek to build up their dossier.

;

;Denying civilians access to food has taken place repeatedly in conflict. Recent examples include Syria, where the Bashar Assad government was accused of pursuing a ;“kneel or starve”; strategy to force opposition areas into submission during the country's civil war – and in Tigray, Ethiopia ;where 2 million people were estimated; to be suffering from a shortage of food from 2020, stemming from a government blockade of the rebel province.
